Will you make a history of 2020 video because the year is gonna be shit?

no. i've watched society at large complain about how every year is garbage. 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, etc. At the end of every year, everyone always seemed to insist that whatever the current year is is the most garbage. well it's too late. you can't say that anymore. every year is great. you are great, we all are great, everything is great. this whole world is fuckin great. get used to it
when showing lyrics on the screen, should they pop up one syllable at a time or one word at a time?

in my experience, i can say that full words are usually better. but in the case of multiple syllable words, especially where there is a heavily emphasized syllable later in the word, it is good to have some emphasis there also, while still revealing the whole word at the beginning of the word. hope this makes sense. it might seem counter intuitive, but i've just found that in most cases it's usually too awkward to see half the word. but try both. see for yourself

a "friend" of mine and I had a heated discussion because he thinks only what is previously imagined and rehearsed can be called "music", ruling out improvised music as being "weaker", "inadequate to express feelings and touch people", and "not really music" (his words). he thinks saying that two composers, one that studied a lot of music theory and one that doesn't have the same amount of theoretical/technical (related to mastering an instrument) knowledge, have the same right to call themselves composers and not be seen as being on different "levels" is devaluing and harmful to music and the development of musicianship. I, on the other hand, think art is not simply about knowledge and technique as it very much is about expression as well, and each artist is free to decide which tools they are going to use to express themselves and how. there's no need for "levels", "better and worse": there's no need to rank artists according to their ability, what' s the po int in having a "caste system" in art? who benefits from that? if he thinks knowing all that he can know about music theory is what works for him, that's great!, for him. but it doesn't mean everyone should follow the same path, otherwise they aren't "actual musicians". what gets me the most is he teaches childre music, and it hurts me to think how he might be one of those teachers I so deeply disliked when I was a kid: people who think they hold the Entire and Absolute Artistic Truth in their hands because they're adults and teachers and they studied some, and therefore they have the right and duty to trim kids' (and people in general's) thoughts. 
I know you are a person and your opinion is also subjective. I also know, from following you and your work, that you don't appear to be close-minded at all. maybe that's why I'm here: reassurance. I firmly believe in what I said about art: I think about it a lot and I change my mind, I try to be as open as I can to new ideas , but th ere's also a core value of art not needing to be constrained, and the importance of artistic freedom, that I keep throughout my life. but am I the unreasonable one in this situation? we are often blind to our own flaws, most of all when they touch us deeply. is that the case here?

sorry for the wall of text.

how do you manage to make so many tunes? i keep trying to make songs, but whenever i open up a music program, i can never think of anything original or nice or even bad, and i keep trying but it never happens, and then i get sad and cry and give up

oh my gosh, you are very in need of a very critical piece of advice and life experience that i must tell you. i have become quite certain, at least for me, that i should NEVER attempt to write a song in the studio. by that i mean, do not attempt to write your song while the recording software/equipment is open. That doesn't mean you can't, but what i have found is that most of the time, if i try to write a song in the 'recording studio', the result is exactly what you just described. this is exactly why, after experimenting a little with the 'write in studio' approach somewhere around 2011, i came to a firm realization that i MUST write and finish the song BEFORE bringing it to the official recording environment. so so important. Recording a song, has enough unknowns and challenges. not even knowing how it goes is WAY too many unknowns. my policy is, i must know how it goes, i need to know every word, every melody, chords, and what's also particularly important to me is that i have the exact 'road map', which means know exactly how long everything goes -- no uncertainty about the ending, no uncertainty about transitions, intros, etc etc, no uncertainty about how it gets from point a to point b. the whole roadmap must be known from beginning to end. not necessary to have every little auxiliary detail, not even necessary to know all the exact instrumental parts. but, you just need the exact melody, lyric, chord, full road map. and also important to have an exact tempo marking, to avoid what i call a 'tempo crisis.' This is just what i've found. not knowing this will cause things to crumble in the studio, at least that is definitely the case when working by yourself. This is not necessarily true for everyone, and i'm sure this approach is more applicaple to people doing the entire arrangement on their own (like me, and perhaps you too). and i'm aware that many many many people write songs in the studio, and i'm sure some people can do it just fine, but i have become quite sure that, for me, without a shadow of a doubt, the 'write first' approach is a must for me, and after reading your story i would strongly advise this for you also. i hope this helps

a blender 2.82 User :)

there is something quite like that. i have it mapped to a regular space bar on another keyboard, but looking into it it seems like it's just F3. however, i can't guarantee that that's the default, i may have switched the key blender uses. To find out, go to preferences, go to 'keymap', and in the search bar type 'search' and you should see something called 'window search', and it should say what key it is, which for me is saying F3 but i can't remember if that's the default setting. Another thing you might find useful, for example, in the node editor windows, whenever you press 'shift A' to add something, that menu has a search thing in it, so in that case it would be 'shift A', 'S' to trigger that, if you happen to be in a node editor window which will allow you to search nodes to add. some of the other sections probably have search tricks hiding in them as well, but as i said the main one is called 'window search' and it's F3 on mine which may or may not be the default but you can find out in the preferences and set it to your own choice

I want to buy a pen tablet for digital drawing, do you think the "One by Wacom" is as good as the Intuos?

well, the problem i'm having with the intuos on mac os 10.14 is that it just doesn't stay connected. While i'm drawing it stays connected, but let's say i do some other things (not drawing), maybe have lunch, go to bed, etc etc etc. Then, when i go to draw again, ok it's time to draw i would like to draw now please, ... it just does not work. I am specifically talking about wired mode (forget bluetooth). The only reliable way to make the thing work is to log out and log in again, you have to do this each time you want to start drawing on a new day basically. i am pretty disappointed because it is supposed to be a high quality tablet which is pretty expensive. The only other wacom experience i had was with the 2012 wacom bamboo which i was using on mac os 10.6.8, for years and years, and worked perfectly, always, any time i needed it. Besides this, another side note which i have learned about a graphics tablet is i think i have concluded that a small tablet is actually better. unless it has an actual display on it in which case larger would be better but that's almost a different product entirely, and a very different price range, more comparable to an ipad or touch laptop

yes. the trick is, there is a tangle in the logistics of the exact steps and methods of HOW, on a very simplistic level. there are some very important unknowns here that you are unable to find the answers for, because you have not clearly located the questions. but they are there. untangling these small issues will cause magnificent surges of fresh unique inspiration that are so distinctively you that you will not be able to resist the seemingly automatic forward motion that will occur as a result. it will be as easy and addictive as chips, but lightyears more powerful. i am narrowing it down to 2 issues here: 1 is the tangled confusion of issues you know somewhere deep within your mind need to be answered, but are buried too deep to remember the details, and the other issue is simply the fear that this song will be your only song. which, to be fair, it may seem that way based on your observation of the current pace. the important rule here is that every song gets better, but i realize this doesn't help if the pace does not seem commensurate with any realistic progress timeframe. So, you need to approach this tangle. It's important to recognize that recording and arranging your own songs is by nature a very tangly and complicated mess. for this reason, it is vitally important that you practice simplicity at all costs, in every aspect of the arrangement. always remember, there was once a time when people had to record on 4 track tape machines and the only way to get more tracks was to burn 3 tracks down to 1, never being able to change them again. in some ways i'm sure your computer software is crippling because it affords you too many options. so simplicity is necessary at all costs, and i think you can expect to have to remind yourself that again and again. But as far as untangling the confusion points, i will tell you one thing that is vitally important to me which i cannot live without, and i've done it for years and continue to do it to this day, in fact it saved my day today and rescued me from the sour depths similar to what you described, and continues to save my ass again and again for at least 10 years or more now, and it's this: keeping a very open freeflowing documentation/discussion of your entire thought process and everything relating to the project, and stay especially in touch with the origins of the project and continue to backtrack and re-explain to yourself how and why you started doing this project and everything that led to it and everything that has gone into it. keep a constant open dialogue with yourself, whether in writing, text, audio, video, or all of those at the same time. drench yourself in discussion of the issues. get it all out in the open. it's like a tangled rope. what you have been doing, it seems, as you described it in your question, is trying to pull on the ends of the rope. what i am describing is when you go into a large room, and lay the rope out on the floor and get a better look at how this thing got this way. and the crazy thing is, every time, when you start to solve it and those tangles come out, not only is it wildly refreshing to have a freely untangled rope, what's crazy is all these memories start flooding back to you about every little tangle as it comes out, and suddenly start to remember exactly how all of them got there in the first place. it's like the big bang all over again

In your song "Might Quit" which verses are secretly choruses, because this has been confusing me for a while

ah, that's a good point, and i think you will notice more and more as you listen to more songs over the course of the past 100 years (and next 100 years) ...... any way of naming things in music will seem very useful and yet also seem to break down. in a parallel universe, (or maybe the 1930s, or any time really) there is a whole other 'normal' way for songs to be, which is called "A A B A". the A feels like the verse ..... it also usually has the title. .... and the 'B' feels kind of like a bridge ... the 'B' also might feel like a pre-chorus ... except it goes back to another A. i've done the AABA thing quite a lot, it seems to work well for me. but regardless of what you call anything, the more songs you listen to the more you will hopefully be comfortable with all of this ..... just be warned, you can expect the terms (like 'verse' .. 'chorus' ... or anything) to melt a bit. this is normal

wait so if i walk for 8 hours in the daytime, i won't get stolen? this is news to me. and you didn't take any breaks from walking in the full 8 hours?
i've done it multiple times, but there will certainly be a meal break
did your feet hurt?

the more you are able to work your way up to it, on previous days, the less soreness there will be. if your average daily walk is 1 minute and then you do 8 hours, you'll be fucked. try to increase more gradually over the course of different days
did you wear expensive shoes?
i wear sneakers, but it's important to make sure they have established a comfortable relationship with your feet already. don't do this with brand new sneakers you've never worn before
did you get to your 'destination' and were like "ok time to go back"?

that would depend on my agenda for the day. sometimes there would have already been an engagement scheduled at that destination. i think that is the ideal situation for a mega-walk, is when you actually had to be at that destination at that time, and where a normal person would have taken some form of higher speed transportation. just walk there instead. also, when you get there, it's fun to watch people flip the hell out when they find out where you just walked from
sorry for so many questions. i just feel very inspired. i don't know why i've never thought of just walking for hours with no specific destination but you're totally right.
i think i prefer when there is a destination. that's just me

And how useful is it?

Would you recommend learning it?

if you have recently heard or played any other notes which you know what they are, then, ANY other note that is played, you MUST know what it is. if you can't get that then you need to get that. However, if you have not recently heard any sound or notes or music which you know the actual notes of, like for example if you just woke up in the morning and have no memory of any songs or notes that you can identify, then it is not expected that you be able to blindly identify the next note. having that skill would be called absolute pitch, and it's kind of like when you can identify a note in a completely and absolutely musicless way, with no musical relation to anything. this is a strange skill that is not related to music in any way whatsoever. To get back to your original question, yes i would be able to identify the note, because i can always remember the last note i heard, and i knew what that one was, so therefore i will know what the next one is when i hear it. also when doing this on a physical keyboard it is made even easier by the fact that the keyboard is shaped in such a way that you can eliminate about half of the notes just based on shape of the key physically

hey, so it seems like the only instruments that remain consistent throughout an entire arrangement of yours is like bass and drums. that would make sense to like explainthe fills you do to express the harmony and stuff. i mean there are outliers, the harpsichord on outside. the strings in school. but is this true, more or less?

that might be because when different instruments play the role of the bass, they are all usually called the bass. when different instruments play the role of the drums/percussion, they are always called drums/percussion. however, when many different instruments play the role of the middle/chord/melody range, people like to call those instruments by different names. so mostly i think it's a naming situation you are noticing

what am I supposed to do with my left hand when playing piano? I know some options are "play a deep bass note" or "play a bassline" but I'm more interested in what people are doing when they have both hands in the middleish range of the keyboard and are playing more than one note in the left hand. Is that just a means of playing wide chords?

i doubt it. there's hardly even room for 2 hands in the real chordal zone of the keyboard. if someone else is playing the bass, AND someone else is playing the melody, then what i usually do is tie my left hand behind my back. if you are supposed to play the melody and chords both on the instrument, then you're gonna have to put chords in left hand and melody in right hand and to be honest i don't have a lot of experience doing that. if you have chords and no bass player, and you are singing the melody, then i think you definitely are going to want to take care of the bass in the left hand and chords with the right. so as you can see, the piano is like a banquet table. it is used in all different ways depending on how many and who the guests are and make sure you don't put 2 whole turkeys in the exact same spot

(ref: q.php?date=202003030330)3.3.203:30 am  hey bill, thanks for answering.see i'm in my second year of college, and obviously that's not a place where you want to be lazy, but i have managed to just slip by in grades with some luck and the help of classmates. the point is;i always end up doing things at the last moment, were it be studying for a test or doing homework, i always do them at the last day, at the last hour, but somehow, i have managed to survive, just survive. and now the thing is i don't want to keep doing that, i don't want to be so lazy.

there is no such thing as lazy. if you feel no energy to do something that means you are not getting why it could be so gosh damn much fun. and maybe there is actually no way for it to be fun but i would be skeptical of that because most things are fun, but the trick is you need to unlock the fun. often in your own entirely unique way. and if you haven't figured out how to do that, then it's going to be extremely extremely unappealing to you. like so unappealing it will be completely impossible to move forward with it. so as i said, there is no such thing is 'lazy', it just means you haven't figured out how much fun the thing could be

i have lots of free days and spare time and i know i should use that free time studying or doing my homework, but i just don't want to do either of them, because doing something i don't want to just makes me feel awful, almost miserable, like i'm being forced into doing something i hate.
right, that is nature's way of saying don't do bad stuff. pretty handy how it says that
but at the same time i know i should not feel that way and i should be more responsible .
doing bad stuff is not responsible. the question is, is the thing actually good and you just haven't unlocked its creamy goodness

do you ever get that feeling when you look at someone else's work, be it art/music/something else, and it has this inherent, irreplicable specialness to it that no one could ever imitate in a million years no matter how hard they tried, and then you look at your own work and you just don't get that feeling?
occasionally, but that mostly depends on my mood

like your own work seems so blatant and manifest in what it's trying to do that no one could ever possibly look at it and say "wow, i wonder how/why they chose to do it that way" or "what does this weird/ambiguous detail mean, what was the creator thinking when they inserted that?" like even if you tried purposely to insert those weird/ambiguous things it wouldn't work or be interesting because you would just inserting them for the sake of trying to be weird/interesting? like I just want to know how to make genuinely interesting things that are interesting for their own sake and not just for the sake of trying to be interesting, but I worry that  I don't  have "what it takes". like maybe the fact that I'm so worried about whether or not what i make is genuinely interesting is actually an indicator that i'm not a person capable of making interesting things

i think it depends on how badly you want it, and if you think to yourself 'yes, that's how badly i want it' then the funny thing is i think you will find out that you already have it. the major hint i can give you for this is that it will be exactly what you want it to be, but the problem is because it's so new you may not have seen it before. so you may have to launch a bit of a search coalition. this may seem scary, but i promise it is fun. so fun that you probably won't worry about it not being interesting, instead you will be scared that you can't find enough places to distribute all of the interestingness so you don't drown in all the interestingness

What's that funky chord in Stacy's mom? The "not the girl for me" part

Is it like 3^7 -> 6min?

they are using distorted guitars, so in reality they will probably just play a lowish C in unison (song is in the key of E, for reference), but on paper as a song i would certainly say it's C° to C#min there. so in that sense making the C a 'power chord' would be rude, but not entirely a crime. they might have done it that way. or they might have fashioned it into a diminished chord actually, if only slightly. which can get kinda bloody on distorted guitars. anyway, i call it C° to C#min. and again for C#min the similar story applies, except for that one the 'power chord' status is not discouraged, it is helpful and likely. i'm just giving my professional opinion, i have not specifically consulted the audio for this question, although i am familiar with the song in general and have heard it several times before. And before i forget- to harken back to your original answer, yes absolutely correct, although again i would recommend putting the bass on C. which i'm 90% is what they did but as i said this is just from the way i remember it. Ok i'm going to stop being lazy and just go listen to it since i have already rambled on it for this long: ok yes, they have C in the bass, and F# in there also. which is the best all around compromise. executing the Cdim which as i said would be quite bloody on the distortion but that's the way it goes. it's always a challenge to make this kind of real harmony happen with distortion on (basically anything except 5ths and 4ths will make a mess) but yea, they did exactly what i would recommend. played it right down the middle, using C and F# notes to approximate Cdim in just enough detail to work properly while still keeping the sludge to a minimum
